item.title: Scott Cate - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: The 2018⁄2019 “Microsoft Ignite | The Tour” global event recently completed in Mumbai. The event took place in 17 cities around the world. Myself and other advocates joined forces with MVPs and Microsoft product specialists and experts to share current thinking around how to build amazing systems and services in the cloud and how to keep them up and running reliably. In the coming weeks I’ll provide a full retrospective on the event and the seven cities I had the pleasure of visiting while on tour.

item.title: Christina Warren - Microsoft | Ignite Tour
item.description: Christina and I first met during the Cloud Advocate Summit right after I joined the team at Microsoft. We had a full day of speaker training and were paired up on our first excercise. Personally knowing only a handful of people on the team prior to joining, I had researched a few people on the roster, Christina quickly surfaced in my online searches. Host of “This week on Channel 9”, Christina is one of the most knowledgable and charismatic people I know.

item.title: Rick Claus - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: I’ll never forget my very first day on campus as a full-time Microsoft Azure Advocate. Especially my first “real” meeting with members of my team - a discussion around the process of updating documentation found on Microsoft Docs! I couldn’t believe it. Here I was sitting around a table with others reviewing how we could submit changes and new content to online resources used by so many. Leading the conversation was Rick Claus.

item.title: Laurent Bugnion - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: Laurent and I had the pleasure of taking part in the first two stops on last year’s Microsoft Ignite | The Tour in Berlin and Sau Paulo. Since then we’ve met up at a number of cities around the world. A true polymath on technical topics, Laurent delivered a number of different sessions throughout the tour. Be sure to check out some of the talks below as well as a few other areas Laurent likes to dabble in.

item.title: Jay Gordon - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: Jay and I joined Microsoft around the same time and for a brief moment were even on the same team within the larger Cloud Advocacy team. Every time we got to speak at the same stop on the Microsoft Ignite | The Tour, we tended to gravitate towards each other and despite vastly different tastes in music, we have a lot in common and it’s always good to catch up.

item.title: Jeremy Likness - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: If you’ve ever seen Jeremy give a talk, you start to understand just how much he knows about a large number of topics. Co-host of “On .NET”, Jeremy teaches me something new each time I interact with him. Check out a couple of the presentations he gave during the Microsoft Ignite | The Tour in Amsterdam below. Tour Presentations: Azure Fundamentals DEV10 - Designing resilient cloud applications DEV50 - Investing in Serverless: less servers, more code Hot Topics .

item.title: Ari Bornstein - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: Every time I get to hang out with Ari is a good work trip. The moment I saw him carrying around a copy of Daniel Kahneman’s “Thinking Fast & Slow”, I knew we would get along well. Aside from behavorial economic theory, Ari and I have had the pleasure of connecting on several stops during the Microsoft Ignite | The Tour and I’m looking forward to teaming up with him on a few artificial intelligence projects - something I’m starting to explore more myself.

item.title: Damien Brady - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: When you chat with Damien about literally any topic, you quickly realize YOU KNOW NOTHING .. and ALSO, he’s really REALLY good at explaining things. If you have a few minutes, give the “Using Artificial Intelligence to Augment Data” presentation from this past Microsoft Ignite | The Tour a watch. It was one of my favorites from the entire tour. It’s pretty crazy how easy it is to start using AI and Machine Learning to assist with different aspects of just about any business.

item.title: Ryan Levick - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: Ryan and I haven’t had a ton of opportunities to work together so far, but each time we do chat I realize I have a lot to learn. One specific area I want to learn more from Ryan about is on the topic of Rust. He gave a great internal presentation on the benefits of using Rust, especially from an Operations-work point of view. The increased security aspect of it is enough to take a closer look if you are a traditional C# developer.

item.title: Erik St. Martin - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: Hands-down… the most amazing experience of this year’s “Microsoft Ignite | The Tour” was riding along with Erik in a Ferrari 488 Spider through not only the streets of Milan but along Lake Como and up the mountain to the observatory. Check out this video I made of the experience. You’d be hard pressed to find anyone who knows more about Kubernetes than Erik and that’s exactly what he was in Amsterdam to talk about when we got another chance to hang out.

item.title: Neil Peterson - Microsoft Ignite | The Tour
item.description: Neil and I had several really great trips together this year during the Microsoft Ignite | The Tour including a layover in Zermatt, Switzerland to snowboard the Matterhorn! A wizard at Kubernetes and continuous deployment techniques with Azure Devops, I learn something new from Neil each time I see one of his talks. Check out a couple of the talks Neil delivered while in Amsterdam this past March.

item.title: What A Long Strange Trip It's Been
item.description: Just over four years ago, I impulsively responded to a Facebook post about a devops evangelism role at a new tech startup. I had never been an evangelist and I knew nothing of the term “devops”. #yolo ¯_(ツ)_/¯ This spontaneous act illuminated a path of personal and professional growth. A path that created new opportunities for me almost daily. A path that changed me for the better. A path that wasn’t there… until it was.

item.title: Five Things
item.description: 5 – Things Developers Can Use To Go On-call (and Not Hate Their Life) As service reliability and uptime become increasingly more important for organizations building applications, developers are now being exposed to new responsibilities and challenges. Tiered ticketing processes, Network Operations Centers (NOC), along with traditional change and incident management technicques can’t provide the level of response necessary to support rapidly deployed applications requiring high availability and maximum uptime.

item.title: On Call Horror Stories
item.description: A couple of weeks ago while in New York City to speak at QCon, my buddy and co-worker (Jay Gordon) was nice enough to let me take over his home office to record a podcast with the ITSM Crowd. While I was there, we decided it made perfect sense to record an episode of his show “On-call Horror Stories”, of which I have plenty to reminisce over. However, we decided to take a different approach to the conversation.

item.title: Devops Road Trip - 2019
item.description: In 2016, with the help of my amazing team at VictorOps, we put on the initial DevOps Road Trip - a series of events in several tech hubs around the U.S. Starting off in Denver, we took our traveling event to Seattle, Minneapolis, San Francisco, and New York. Each of these free events were held at a unique and memorable venues. In Denver, we invited attendees to Mile High Stadium (where the Denver Broncos play).

item.title: Empowering Users through Site Reliability Engineering
item.description: When.. was the last time you got excited about new technology? What was it? Was it a programming language? Rust, Go, Node.js? Maybe a new framework? Angular, React? Or was it something like serverless or containers? Azure functions, Docker, Kubernetes? Think back on what it was. Do you have something in your mind? Ok, now … How did you learn about it? Likely from a friend or colleague introducing it to you, right?

item.title: Minimum Viable Incident Response Plan
item.description: Small Problem - Large Cost On Wednesday, August 1st 2012 an 18 year old financial services firm began a test run of their new trading software. Carefully configured to interact with a very small number of stocks and with Buy and Sell points set well outside where the markets were trading that day, a reasonable amount of caution was taken to reduce the blast radius in the unlikely event anything should go wrong.

item.title: Bio
item.description: Jason Hand Senior Cloud Ops Advocate @ Microsoft Jason writes, presents, and coaches on the principles and nuance of DevOps, Site Reliability Engineering, and modern incident management practices. Named “DevOps Evangelist of the Year” by DevOps.com in 2016, Jason recently authored a new book on the topic of Site Reliability Engineering. In addition to SRE, Jason has authored books with O’Reilly Media on the subject of post-incident reviews and Chatops.
